page_analysis.text_content:
Fig 21 Plan view showing how to determine average grade

When measuring daylight plane, height is measured from the average of the grade at the
midpoint of the building and the grade of the closest point on the abutting site.

For this side of this structure, the
average grade is the average
of the grades at these two
points

the top of the roof
material

Certification of daylight plane compliance:

Upon request by the building official any person
building or making improvements to a structure shall
provide a certification that the structure, as built, com-
plies with the daylight plane provisions in Code Section
18.12.040(a). Such certification shall be prepared
by a licensed engineer, architect, or surveyor, and
shall be provided prior to frame inspection. (Sections
18.12.040(j)).

27

visual_elements.description: A plan view diagram illustrating how to determine average grade for a 'Subject House' and a 'Neighbor' property. It shows lot lines, required setbacks, buildable areas, and front, rear, and interior-side yards. Arrows and text indicate how the average grade is calculated based on two points for each side of the structure. The diagram includes a street/sidewalk area at the bottom.
visual_elements.location: Left and bottom-left of the page

visual_elements.description: A cross-section diagram showing a roof structure, a 'wall plane', and a 'daylight plane'. It illustrates an allowable eave protrusion, indicating that the daylight plane must clear the point where the wall plane intersects the top of the roof material.

A key defining symbols used in the plan view diagram: 'Lot line' (solid line), 'Required setbacks' (dashed line), 'Sidewalk' (patterned rectangle), 'Buildable area' (light gray shaded area), and 'Existing house' (dark gray shaded area).

sections: Fig 21 Plan view showing how to determine average grade
Fig 22 Detail showing allowable eave protrusion

additional_notes: The word 'from' in the sentence 'height is measured trom the average' appears to be a typo or OCR error, likely intended as 'from'.
The page number '27' is present at the bottom right corner.
